comments.commentBody: fsmlives, point well made.
now thats good irony

and Elke
Quickly got BUDDIES and INVITRO and the TREVI as rebi. After solving for the reveal, figured math was involved, to whit DD= 1000, divide by VI, and you see where I wind up.
Fortunately JMK provides at 43D "humble oneself", so I am EATing DIRT. There is also the cure- SCOPE.
Am making a note of Jonathan Kaye's predilection for splitting letters (at least they are not atoms ). He is on my list now.
Wish I had figured this one out on my own. It is really clever.
And knowing the term EAT DIRT, I was waiting before I decided if it would be CROW or DIRT on the menu today.

Another hand up for EAT CROW.

Neither possibility passes my literal breakfast test, but a nice piece of--well, not misdirection, but ambiguity--to come across so late in the puzzle.

Agree that the revealer being self-referential with the theme was an added twist - took me a long while at the very end to fill in the SE corner - but was very enjoyable.

Didn't see the notepad note till after I'd solved the puzzle. So am a bit perplexed by all the hoop-la after I got here! M

Thank you.

I come from a blue collar family in a blue collar area, which seems to set me apart from most NYT readers.

You are 100% right and those who doubt you simply don't get out much among people who are different from themselves.

If we are to have a strong, stable country we need decent jobs for every skill and temperament.

In 1980, right before President Ronald Reagan held in September 1981 in Gran Rapids, Michigan the first Summit with the Prime Minister of Canada and the President of Mexico planting the seed for NAFTA, 98 Million people had jobs in the U.S.  That number has increased to around 150 Million people by now.  A gain, NOT A LOSS, of more than 50 Million jobs!  Now, it is well known that the jobs of today are very different than the jobs of the 1980s and those who did not bother to acquire the skills that the technology driven economy of today requires most likely can't get a job.  So Let's Make Them happy Again! by closing all universities and research centers and go crazy with coal mining!  That is how we will Make America Great Again!  Are we crazy?

Things are so good that the real median household income is now about what it was 20 years ago!

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Household_income_in_the_United_States

You are over-simplifying, but rather than try to teach a short course on the economics of international trade, I will refer you to the Baltic Dry Index (BDI), which is a measure of shipping costs. The BDI has fallen over the past two years, because of an over-supply of shipping capacity. That is bad for shipping suppliers, but good for shipping consumers. Here is a superb article on the BDI:

The Surprising Relevance of the Baltic Dry Index
By Jeffrey Rothfeder
The New Yorker
June 22, 2016
http://www.newyorker.com/business/currency/the-surprising-relevance-of-t...

Google for more info on the BDI.

If there were still decent paying manufacturing jobs that paid good wages people wouldn't need to shop at Walmart. We're things really so bad that we needed to increase trade to this point? Is 10% cheaper baby clothes and strawberries in winter worth the loss of millions of jobs and the destruction of our jobs in our manufacturing base.

Weren't we supposed to transition to a "service economy"? But those Walmart service jobs don't pay or offer the same economic purchasing power that a decent Union job at a mill or auto plant did.

It seems we have up a lot as a society for such free trade which in the end really only benefited corporations, those in their higher management, and this that trade or fund their shares.

Not to digress but even all the airline mergers haven't brought tickets down that much and they've made traveling to much of middle America a nightmare of plane connections.

Ross Perot was right about Nafta. And a lot of people warned of the impact of having China join the WTO, but both were good for corporations to get access to way cheaper labor. Capital and goods are free to move around the globe now, but labor is prisoner to their boarders and communities. It's not a fair economic model.

Sadly, this year has turned out to be a no-win choice for people voting for either candidate. Voting for the "lesser" may get Hillary CLinton to win, but what is the USA going to truly get?

Up here in Canada it's business as usual as voters are "getting the business" from the Liberals who have been in power for one year. Some promises are not being met, and we, the voters threw out one demagogue for another. MInd you, Mr. Trudeau started out well, but there have been minor scandals here and as I mentioned, some promises have not been met.

We did have another party the last time that was the official opposition (New Democratic Party), but voters didn't like them either. So for now it's 3 more years of the Liberals.

Bottom line, one party may be blue and the other Red (like in the USA), but neither keeps their promises when elected, and there is no one else to vote for.

Voting for Mrs. CLinton is better than not voting or voting for a third party, but how much better will the Democrats actually be after having been in power for the last 8 years?
I did it on clues but had no idea why those letters signified "BY" until I read this page...still don't really care.  Seems too clever by half..

This article wants us to look at the "devastation" that working-class people experience in the developed world. But what about the developing world? What about people being lifted out of poverty by millions? China is portrayed by Trump supporters as some malevolent juggernaut snatching bread out of the mouths of American children. But China is composed of people just like you and me: mothers, fathers, families. Fifty years ago more than 40 million Chinese starved to death. Look me in the eye and tell me that I should care more for some American guy's declining standard of living than for a little girl's stripping bark off a tree because she has nothing else to fill her stomach. Global trade saves lives. Yes, blue-collar workers in the developed world are paying the price but it's nothing compared to the price others have paid for centuries.
Hopefully those 40 million Chinese will vote for Clinton, and save us from Trump, right?   You can't write off millions of Americans, and hope there will be no consequences.
Mor, your comment employs pretzel logic. Since when must one population suffer in order for another to overcome poverty?

Well, I can't look you in the eye, but I can respond.  When these trade agreements were worked out Congress decided that the benefits to their corporate sponsors were more important than the vast labor force of the United States. The idea that we are lifting up millions in other countries when those millions were not our problem in the first place is idealistic.  We are dealing with reality here and the reality is that trade agreements benefit only  the 1%.  And it isn't just the 1% in the US.  Did you not read the opening paragraphs of the article?

This is the stupidest idea I've heard since the debate Monday night. Why would a given state surrender their sovereignty to the will of the other 49 states? How about this instead: divide the state's electoral votes according to the percentage of the vote won by each candidate in that state? That would protect state sovereignty while nullifying the "winner take all"flaw in the current system.

On the other hand, one of the fundamental ideas behind the Electoral College was to produce a clear-cut winner and avoid repeating a 2000-ish miasma.

The biggest problem about US trade nobody is pointing out is that much of the profits earned by companies from cheap labor have not come back home to be taxed and thus provide the government to better compensate the workers who lost their jobs. Most of the benefits went to the executives in high compensation and stock holders in higher prices of their stock.

This election is about payback.  America's companies and politicians blamed the free market as they laid off long time employees.  Now they wonder why those former employees want to punish them by voting for the outsider, Donald Trump.  As the old adage goes,  what comes around goes around.  Loyalty is dead.

True.  There are three actors in the Constitution:  the federal government, the states, and the citizens.  Do not forget that the federal government was created by the states, not vice versa.  The imbalance to this original formula, introduced by the Seventeenth Amendment, have now become the chickens coming home to roost.

The Goring of Hillary is only a fraction of why the race is tighter.
Hillary has spent a lot of money on ineffective negative ads attacking Trump. She is using the same failed strategy that Jeb Bush used in the Republican primaries. Everyone knows already about Trump's negatives. Hillary needs positive ads to tell voters they should vote for her, that she is on their side--with specifics about what she will do to help people and how she will make life better for them. Don't mention Hillary's website. Boring...Pick the best Clinton policies and repeat again and again.
The received wisdom is that negative ads work but this election is different because Trump is such an unusual candidate. The Current Clinton ads give Trump more air time--the opposite of what they should be doing.

Agree. What is this campaign then? Just go to my website?

Why does a candidate focus on the other side’s negatives and not give specifics on what she will do to make life better for the majority? And, why has her supporter, Krugman, been focusing constantly on the same thing?

Maybe she avoids making promises she won’t live up to?
While strategists and lawyers write the website?

My district went about 75% for Hillary in the primary, so my vote really doesn't count.  Given an electoral system where the popular vote really does not count, it's foolishness to pretend that "every vote counts".  The only votes that count are those in swing districts, and then only if they are swing states.  So if you're in Pennsylvania or Ohio, you are lucky to be in a democracy and your vote counts.  If you live in New York or Massachusetts, your winner is already picked, you might as well stay home.  I'll either do that or write in Bernie.
I live in Indiana.. I feel your pain. Except the natives here, except for me, think's Trump's blow and bluster will save their skins.

Oh Bill, this is a terrible message. There are so many down-ballot races. There are ballot initiatives. Don't ever tell people to stay home just because the presidential "winner is already picked" in their state.

Your logic is why the Republican Party has crushed the Democratic Party in House races, in governors' races, in school board races, in county commissioner races, ad infinitum. Please rethink your outlook!

Bill,
Careful. Your not following the status quo meme being parroted right now.
You free thinkers are a danger.
Congrats.

@ash
It begs to wonder if any of these people have even taken a look at the website, which expains Clinton's plans -- Or, is this just a knee-jerk reaction?
It isn't an insult.  It is the truth that all Americans should take into account in deciding who and what to vote for.  The real insult is to our national interest when they don't.

Bash and mock the Ogre Trump all you want -- the truth is he saw and gave voice to this outrage first--  long before Hillary -- who was still backing the transpacific trade agreement, giving private speeches to Goldman Sachs, and using her Secretary of State position to collect $100 million from foreign governments-- she was clueless about the impact of free trade on US workers until the Trump movement made it the central issue of this campaign.

Nope. Young voters don't know exactly what is at stake in this election, and they will be reaping what they sow for at least the next 4 years. If Trump becomes president, they will have a supreme court unfriendly to freedom of choice and biased towards corporations over individual rights and that may be more than 4 years. It will cost the economy $1 Trillion dollars - that would be a lot of jobs for young people. The current estimate for a Trump budget sees a $5.3 trillion increase in national debt - medicare and other benefits the government now provides will be slashed, even though it is proportionally insignificant. Americans will most likely feel and be less safe and have fewer allies in the global community.

All it will cost Hillary is the presidency - she can go back to work for the Clinton foundation, and have an otherwise comfortable life. To put it bluntly, the rich, including most politicians will still do ok. The poor and the young not so much.

So if the point of the exercise is that the young will demonstrate how miserable they will be with President Trump and how much it will cost them, then I really don't get the logic of it. It is just spoilt, self indulgent behaviour mixed in with a healthy dose of self harm.
She, along with Sanders, backs a program to make college free for students from families with less than $125,00. annual income.

The article here has to do with young voters who are not the same as older voters. Many of them don't fall for the "Big Scare", and may vote for a third party candidate or not vote. They have seen that both parties once elected have their own agendas, and many promises are left out of the agenda for their term(s) in office. They're totally disenfranchised with the system, and see that there does;t seem to be any difference once  the other party gets elected. In this case, it's Mrs. Clinton's baggage still continues to haunt her!

"The Electoral College must remain if we are continue on as the United States of America"  Why??  I believe it is in fact a dis-uniting part of our country.  As this article makes clear most of us are spectators (e.g. California will be for Clinton and Idaho will be for Trump) and only a few states decide the election.  The Electoral College may be very difficult to get rid of since smaller states (e.g. Idaho) get more power per person than large states (e.g. California) and they will fight hard to keep it.  If elections were based on congressional districts rather than national popular vote the political payoff for gerrymandered districts would be even higher than it is now.  Given the current state I would not favor that.  The only fair method is one person one vote and election on the basis of a national popular vote.  Regardless, it is clear that the worst system of all that I have seen proposed is the current system.
Doug:  The problem is that nobody would believe Hillary would actually implement any program she comes up with for the millennials.
comments.userDisplayName: Looking at it from another angle...

comments.commentBody: Eight years of Bush didn't sink the country. Eight years of Obama didn't save the country. Why should voters think in four year chunks?

8 years of Bush hurt the country greatly!

It brought wars, massive loss of life, a failed response to Hurricane Katrina, a tax giveaway to the rich, a large scale program of domestic spying, an economic meltdown-- the worst since the Great Depression, a right wing judiciary that set back the cause of human rights, ruled corporations are people, opened up the electoral process to unlimited corporate money, curbed women's rights, etc.

Sorry, but you've created a false equivalency!

That's the problem. We are thinking in chunks of 4 and 8. But Reaganism began more than 30 years ago, before the so-called millenials were born. They don't remember the country's fight to move left in the 1960s and its drift toward political indifference in the '70s. This indifference on the left led to Reagan being elected by a cohort of right-wing boomers and their parents who were still terrified of communism and hippies.

It was that election that brought us to where we are today. At the time my tiny generation of young people could see that Reagan spelled disaster for everything that the left held dear. We didn't have the numbers to outvote the boomers. We watched political progress be devoured by the corporate monsters that rule the world today. Our protests fell on deaf ears. Now the rest of the country is suffering from the consequences of an election young people were protesting 30 years ago!

The presidency has become the only thing stopping a gerrymandered House of Representatives from handing the country on a silver platter to the wealthy and the fundamentalist religions. The millenials gave me hope again, but they are falling into the trap of impatience. The ship of state is huge and doesn't turn quickly. We can elect HRC who will at least try to keep the right wing at bay while the rest of us get up off our butts and get a better organized left-wing political base that will really do something to turn the ship around. Real change requires long-term commitment.

comments.userDisplayName: Looking at it from another angle...
comments.commentBody: Congress supported Bush.
